content.description:
This is an awesome climb up the secluded Wiggins Wall. The hairy part is right before the small tree and ledge about halfway up, but it's well-protected.

To descend, scramble to the top and then downclimb the southwest side of the crag or rappel off the south bluff.
content.protection: 9 bolts, two bolt anchor. Well-protected moves.
content.location: Go south past all the other walls. Go west on a path right before you pass a cave on your right and veer south to the cliff base. Scramble up a third class slab to a belay anchor and ledge.

climbs.name: Smear Campaign
climbs.fa: Stewart Green, Martha Morris, and Mike Heinrichs, Sept. 2004

content.description:
From the guidebook: Excellent moderate route on the right side of the face.  Begin by scrambling up to a 1-bolt anchor in a scoop below central wall.  Traverse right on third class rock for 60 feet to a bolt at a small belay stance.  Smear up the undulating slab above to a headwall.  Work up right along a line of flakes to a hole with a large crystal-line xenolith ("strange rock").  Anchors are on a narrow shelf above.

Caution: The flake towards the top is loose.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor (there is a belay bolt as well, and it's pretty high up and could be mistaken to the first bolt).
content.location: This route is the farthest right route on Wiggins' Wall.  You can find it from the shady area by scrambling up the rock and traversing (approximately 60 feet) to the right, you'll see the belay bolt roughly 30-45 feet from the dirt line (bear in mind erosion may increase this distance).  It's definitely decent 3rd class hiking to get there.  The anchors when you look at the rock will be just to the left of the bushes that have a small outcropping below them.

content.description:
This is a long 1 pitch route. Start with

Mo' Verde

, but after the first bolt head straight up the wall. The Colorado Climbing guidebook lists this route as a 10a, but there is only 1 or 2 10a moves in the route, mostly it is 9 moves the whole way up. The crux is in between the 3rd and 4th bolts when you are pulling on flakes(pull down, not out!).

Descent: Scramble up above the anchors to top out, and then climb down the back side and around. If you have a 70m rope, you can rap it, too.
content.location: This is on the Wiggins Wall, Red Rock Canyon Open Space, CO Springs.

content.description:
This route is just South of

Smear Campaign

. There are bolts right where you need them. It is a good route that seems to be getting just a bit harder than its original rating.
content.location: Scramble up to a 1 bolt anchor in a scoop below the central wall. Book says to rap with double ropes or a 60 meter, but a 70 meter works better.

content.description: This is a great, sustained, 10c climb that heads straight up the wall from the belay bolt in the scoop ledge. In the Colorado Climbing guidebook, the picture shows it starting by going off left, but the first bolt is almost straight up. You will need a 70m rope if you want to rap down, if you have a 60m rope you can climb off the back side but will need to traverse across the Coyote Wall to get back to the scoop ledge.
content.location: This is on the Wiggins Wall, Red Rock Canyon Open Space, Colorado Springs.

climbs.name: Fringe of Death
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton and Stewart Green, August 2004

content.description: This is a tough route, especially for the grade; broken handholds since its conception easily bring the rating to the 5.10a/b range. Begin with easy moves to a traverse, followed by thin moves to a thin ledge with a tough pull to a good handhold near the anchor.
content.location:
The route is on the southern side of

Wiggins Wall

; follow the trail to

Wiggins Wall

, and follow the line of bolt that goes to the left. It shares a belay anchor at the bottom with

The Youth

(5.10b) and Green Squared (5.10c/d).
